detail.title: üéØ The Question That Changed Everything
detail.content: Prof. Teeters asked me: "HAP, what happens on the 847 screen sizes in between your breakpoints?" and I had NO answer! I was designing for exactly 3 sizes: mobile (320px), tablet (768px), desktop (1024px). But what about 375px? 414px? 1366px? 1920px? That question started my journey from fixed thinking (be exactly this size) to intrinsic thinking (adapt to any size). Now my layouts work on screens I've never even seen!

stations.title: üî¨ Six Learning Stations Overview
stations.content: I built 6 stations covering intrinsic philosophy (Station 1), content-sizing keywords (Station 2), fluid spacing with clamp() (Station 3), flexible grids (Station 4), container queries (Station 5), and AI assistance (Station 6). Each station shares a mistake I made and what Prof. Teeters taught me to fix it!

station1-philosophy.title: üéØ Why Intrinsic Thinking Changed Everything
station1-philosophy.content: Prof. Teeters asked me "HAP, what happens on the 847 screen sizes in between your breakpoints?" and my brain exploded! I realized I was thinking in fixed instructions (be exactly 300px) instead of flexible rules (be between 16rem and 60rem based on space). That question shifted my entire mindset from pixels to intrinsic design.

station1-disasters.title: üí• My 300px Card Disaster
station1-disasters.content: I made these beautiful 300px-wide cards. Mobile (375px)? Horizontal scroll disaster! Tablet (768px)? Tiny and awkward with huge margins! Desktop (1440px)? Cards looked cramped when 600px would fit perfectly! Prof. Teeters showed me width: clamp(16rem, 45vw, 60rem) and suddenly my cards adapted to every screen automatically!

station1-custom-props.title: üé® Custom Properties = Design System
station1-custom-props.content: Prof. Teeters taught me: "Stop using magic numbers, HAP!" Instead of padding: 24px everywhere, I learned --space-md: 1.5rem once, use everywhere. Change one value, update entire site! Now my spacing scale goes from --space-xs to --space-xl and everything stays systematic and consistent!

station2-min-max.title: üìê min-content vs max-content Discovery
station2-min-max.content: min-content = narrowest possible without overflow (text wraps to multiple lines). max-content = one long line, as wide as needed. I tested both on my navigation and the difference was HUGE! min-content made items stack narrow, max-content gave each item its natural width. Prof. Teeters: "Let the content tell you what it needs!"

station2-fit-content.title: üéØ fit-content() Flexible Boundaries
station2-fit-content.content: Prof. Teeters showed me width: fit-content(60ch) for article layouts and I finally understood! Content grows naturally up to 60 characters (perfect reading line length), but never wider. Short paragraphs? Narrow and centered. Long paragraphs? Exactly 60ch wide. No magic number widths needed!

station2-navigation.title: üß≠ Navigation That Knows Its Size
station2-navigation.content: My nav had labels like "Home" (short) and "Documentation" (long). Fixed widths? Looked terrible! Prof. Teeters: "Try width: max-content on each item." Suddenly each nav item was exactly as wide as its label needed‚Äîno more awkward padding or text squishing! Content determined the size automatically!

station3-slope.title: üìä The Computed Slope Formula Secret
station3-slope.content: This was THE critical lesson! Prof. Teeters said: "Never use clamp(1rem, 5%, 3rem)‚Äîthat 5% is unpredictable!" Instead: clamp(min, base + slope √ó 100vw, max) where slope = (max-size - min-size) √∑ (max-viewport - min-viewport). I calculated: clamp(1rem, 0.75rem + 0.625vw, 1.5rem) and it scaled perfectly from 320px to 1920px!

station3-has.title: üîç Content-Aware Spacing Magic
station3-has.content: Prof. Teeters showed me .card:has(img) { padding: 2rem; } and I was AMAZED! Cards with images automatically got more padding. Cards without images stayed compact. No classes needed! The CSS looked at the content and adapted spacing. Mind = blown ü§Ø

station3-mistake.title: ‚ùå My Arbitrary Percentage Mistake
station3-mistake.content: I tried clamp(1rem, 5%, 3rem) because 5% seemed reasonable. Sometimes 5% was HUGE (wide parent), sometimes tiny (narrow parent)! Prof. Teeters explained: "That 5% is relative to the parent element's width, not the viewport! It doesn't scale predictably!" That's when I learned the computed slope formula. Never again!

station4-magic.title: ‚ö° The Magic Pattern Explained
station4-magic.content: grid-template-columns: repeat(auto-fit, minmax(16rem, 1fr)) is pure magic! The browser calculates how many 16rem-minimum columns fit, then gives each equal share of leftover space. Mobile (320px)? 1 column! Desktop (1440px)? 5 columns! Ultrawide (3840px)? 15 columns! No media queries needed! Prof. Teeters: "Stop saying '3 columns'‚Äîstart saying 'as many as fit with 16rem minimum!'"

station4-auto-fit.title: üéØ auto-fit vs auto-fill Finally Clear
station4-auto-fit.content: I was SO confused until I tested side-by-side! auto-fit: Empty tracks collapse, so 3 cards expand to fill space (wider cards). auto-fill: Empty tracks preserved, so 3 cards stay at minimum width (narrower cards). Prof. Teeters: "Use auto-fit 99% of the time‚Äîit makes items expand beautifully!" Now I get it!

station4-bento.title: üç± Bento-Box Spanning Victory
station4-bento.content: I built a dashboard with grid-column: span 2 on featured widgets and it was AMAZING! Desktop (1440px)? Widget spans 2 of 6 columns‚Äînice and big. Tablet (768px)? Spans 2 of 3 columns‚Äîstill featured. Mobile (375px)? Spans 2 of 2 columns‚Äîfull width! The magic pattern calculated columns, spanning created asymmetry, everything still adapted intrinsically!

station5-container.title: üì¶ Container Queries Saved My Life
station5-container.content: My viewport-query card broke in a sidebar! Viewport said "desktop" (1440px) so @media (min-width: 768px) triggered horizontal layout‚Äîbut the sidebar was only 300px wide! Card exploded! Prof. Teeters: "Stop asking 'How wide is the SCREEN?' Start asking 'How wide is MY CONTAINER?'" @container (min-width: 400px) fixed everything!

station5-cqi.title: üìè Container Units = Mind Blown
station5-cqi.content: Prof. Teeters showed me padding: clamp(1rem, 0.5rem + 2cqi, 3rem) and I understood EVERYTHING! cqi = 1% of container inline-size (width). Sidebar (300px container)? Padding is compact (0.5rem + 6px). Main content (900px container)? Padding is generous (0.5rem + 18px). SAME CSS, different containers, perfect adaptation!

station5-aspect.title: üñºÔ∏è Intrinsic Media Ended My Distortion Nightmare
station5-aspect.content: Before aspect-ratio, my images distorted everywhere! Now: aspect-ratio: 16 / 9; object-fit: cover; and images adapt to ANY container, maintain their ratio, never stretch or squish! Sidebar (300px)? Image is 300√ó169. Main (900px)? Image is 900√ó506. Always 16:9, always perfect, always intrinsic!

station6-drift.title: ü§ñ What Is AI Drift Anyway?
station6-drift.content: I asked AI for a card component and got background: #E8A557 (hex!) instead of hsl(32, 76%, 63%). It suggested @media (min-width: 768px) instead of @container. Prof. Teeters explained: "AI tools trained on older code patterns‚Äîthey drift back to 2019 CSS unless you give them context!" That's AI drift!

station6-rules.title: üìã Project Rules File Changed Everything
station6-rules.content: Prof. Teeters taught me to write CLAUDE.md with my project rules: "Use hsl() colors only. Prefer container queries. Computed slopes required." Now AI reads my rules first and generates modern code! No more hex colors, no more arbitrary percentages, no more viewport queries! The rules file is persistent context that prevents drift!

station6-verify.title: ‚úÖ My AI Code Verification Checklist
station6-verify.content: I check EVERY AI suggestion now! Colors in hsl()? ‚úì Container queries not @media? ‚úì Slope formula not arbitrary %? ‚úì Custom properties not magic numbers? ‚úì Prof. Teeters: "Catch drift early, HAP! Don't let bad patterns accumulate!" This checklist saves me SO much refactoring time!
